00034  // Some of this code may have elements taken from other code without attribution.
00035  // If this is the case it was due to oversight while debugging and I apologize.

00038 
00039 #ifndef RING_H
00040 #define RING_H
00041 
00042 #include <stdint.h>
00043 #include <stdbool.h>
00044 
00045 typedef uint16_t ring_index_t;
00046 typedef uint8_t *ring_buffer_t;
00047 typedef uint8_t ring_count_t;
00048 typedef uint8_t ring_size_t;
00049 typedef struct
00050 {
00051     ring_buffer_t buffer;
00052     ring_size_t size;
00053     ring_index_t head_index;
00054     ring_index_t tail_index;
00055     ring_count_t count;
00056 } ring_t;
00057 
00058 /*!
00059         \defgroup ring Ring Buffer
00060 */
00061 
00062 
00063 /** 
00064         \ingroup ring
00065 
00066         \brief Sets up the ring buffer with ring_t parameters.
00067         The clear command is also called to set 0 values within
00068     the ring buffer functions. 
00069     
00070         \code
00071         Example:
00072         void setup()
00073         {
00074                 // Initialize the ring buffer
00075                 if(!ring_init(ring_t *r, ring_buffer_t buffer, ring_size_t size))
00076                 {
00077                         // Buffer not intitialized so handle the error
00078                 }
00079                 
00080         // Okay to use the buffer 
00081         \endcode
00082 
00083         \param r pointer to the ring_t structure
00084         \param buff pointer to buffer you want to use for the ring buffer.
00085         \param size size in bytes of the buffer and must be equal to or greater than 2. he actual amount of storage available in the ring buffer is size - 1.
00086     
00087     \return boolean true if the ring buffer was initialized, false otherwise.
00088 }       
00089 */
00090 bool ring_init(ring_t *r, ring_buffer_t buff, ring_size_t size);
00091 
00092 /** 
00093         \ingroup ring
00094 
00095         \brief This clear function will reset the head_index and tail_index to 0.
00096     The count value is also set to 0. A memset command is used to reset
00097     a particular area in memory as well.
00098         
00099         \code
00100         Example:
00101         void end_this()
00102         {
00103                 ring_clear(&receive_ring);
00104         }
00105         \endcode
00106 
00107         \param *r pointer to ring buffer
00108         
00109         \return boolean result of attempt to add byte
00110 */
00111 bool ring_clear(ring_t *r);
00112 
00113 /** 
00114         \ingroup ring
00115 
00116         \brief This boolean will reference the ring_t structure and add data
00117     to the ring buffer as it increments the index. If data
00118     can be added to the ring buffer, the boolean will then return
00119     a true. If no addition was done, then a false will be
00120     returned.
00121     
00122     \note Data added will be one value less than the size
00123     of the defined ring buffer. An example of this is a buffer
00124     size of [10] will only allow 9 values to be added into the buffer
00125         
00126         \code
00127         Example:
00128         // receive_ring structure defined elsewhere
00129         bool put_byte(uint8_t b)
00130         {
00131                 return(ring_add(&receive_ring, b));
00132         }
00133         \endcode
00134         
00135         \param *r pointer to ring buffer
00136         \param data byte to add
00137         
00138         \return boolean result of attempt to add byte
00139 */
00140 bool ring_add(ring_t *r, uint8_t data);
00141 
00142 
00143 /** 
00144         \ingroup ring
00145 
00146     \brief  Removes a byte of data from the ring buffer.
00147         
00148         \code
00149         // receive_ring structure defined elsewhere
00150         uint8_t get_byte()
00151         {
00152                 return(ring_remove(&receive_ring));
00153         }
00154         \endcode
00155          
00156     \param *r a pointer to the ring_t structure.
00157         
00158     \return The byte of data removed.
00159 */      
00160 uint8_t ring_remove(ring_t *r);
00161 
00162 /** 
00163         \ingroup ring
00164 
00165     \brief Reads uint8_t count bytes from the ring buffer into a new buffer provided 
00166         as a parameter. It does not remove any of the values read from the ring buffer.
00167         Nor does it change the ring buffer indexes.     It returns the number of bytes read.
00168         
00169         \code
00170         Example:
00171         // receive_ring structure defined elsewhere
00172         uint8_t get_bytes(uint8_t *buf, uint8_t count)
00173         {
00174                 return(ring_peek(&receive_ring, buf, count));
00175         }
00176         \endcode
00177          
00178     \param *r a pointer to the ring_t structure.
00179     \param *buf a pointer to a buffer to hold the data.
00180     \param count the number of bytes to load from the ring buffer to buf.
00181         
00182     \return the actual number of bytes read.
00183 */
00184 uint8_t ring_peek(ring_t *r, uint8_t *buf, uint8_t count);
00185 
00186 /** 
00187         \ingroup ring
00188 
00189     \brief Determines if the count is above the highmark used for flow-control.
00190         
00191         \code
00192         Example:
00193         // receive_ring structure defined elsewhere
00194         void do_something()
00195         {
00196                 if(ring_above_highmark(&receive_ring))
00197                 {
00198                         pause_reception();
00199                 }
00200                 else
00201                 {
00202                         continue_reception();
00203                 }
00204         }
00205         \endcode
00206          
00207     \param r a pointer to a ring_t structure.
00208         
00209     \return true if the count is >= 3/4 of the buffer size.
00210 */
00211 bool ring_above_highmark(ring_t *r);
00212 
00213 /** 
00214         \ingroup ring
00215 
00216     \brief Determines if the count is belowthe lowmark used for flow-control.
00217         
00218         \code
00219         Example:
00220         // receive_ring structure defined elsewhere
00221         void do_something()
00222         {
00223                 if(ring_above_lowmark(&receive_ring))
00224                 {
00225                         start_transmission();
00226                 }
00227                 else
00228                 {
00229                         wait_till_later();
00230                 }
00231         }
00232         \endcode
00233          
00234     \param r a pointer to a ring_t structure.
00235         
00236     \return true if the count is <= 1/4 of the buffer size.
00237 */
00238 bool ring_below_lowmark(ring_t *r);
00239 
00240 /* ring buffer counter initialization */
00241 #define ring_free_count(r)      (((r)->size) - ((r)->count))
00242 
00243 #endif
